name: Yin and Yang
shortDescription: Fundamental duality of complementary opposites that constitute all existence
fullDescription: Yin and Yang (Èô∞ÈôΩ, yƒ´n y√°ng) is the foundational principle in Chinese philosophy describing the dualistic yet complementary nature of all phenomena. Yin (Èô∞) represents qualities like darkness, passivity, femininity, cold, moon, earth, and receptivity, while Yang (ÈôΩ) embodies light, activity, masculinity, heat, sun, heaven, and creativity. Rather than absolute opposites, yin and yang are interdependent, transforming into each other in cyclical patterns. All things contain both aspects in varying proportions, and balance between them creates harmony. This concept underlies Chinese cosmology, medicine, martial arts, and spiritual practice.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Yin and yang symbolize the fundamental nature of reality - that all phenomena arise from the interplay of complementary opposites. The symbol (‚òØ) shows each containing the seed of the other, representing constant transformation. The curved boundary suggests dynamic movement rather than rigid separation. Perfect balance is the ideal but constantly shifting state.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Yin-yang is perhaps the most recognizable symbol of Chinese philosophy worldwide. It influences every aspect of Chinese culture from medicine to cooking, architecture to martial arts. The principle has been adopted globally as a symbol of balance, harmony, and holistic thinking.

sources.author: Attributed to Fuxi and King Wen
